reviewText:
I have a hard time speaking in a balanced manner about Mass Effect 2 because it's one of my single favorite video games of all-time. There are so many good things to gush over, but the bad pieces are really, truly bad and do a lot to ruin the experience of actually playing the game. The most concise way I can describe it is 'flawed masterpiece'. It's a game propped up by fantastic art and sound design and far better overall writing than the much maligned Mass Effect 3, but at the same time, the gameplay is nowhere near as tight and the overall design is way rougher -- To the point where I'd criticize the combat as being unfinished.

To start, the graphics and the engine run pretty smoothly on the PC. It runs easily enough -- I see around 110-120 FPS on my 120hz 1440p monitor, but the textures are often muddy and low-res, a curse of the title being designed with far outdated consoles in mind... Even back in 2010. I had a similar experience with the first Mass Effect, though that game is even rougher-looking than this one is. The textures here are, on average, higher res. It helps that the lighting is far better designed than the first game (goodbye, ham-fisted lens flare!). There are a great many visual bugs, though. Far more than the console version. Glitches with the eyes, characters model inexplicably spinning, etc. But it's saved mostly by the beautiful art design. The use of colored lighting really adds a great touch, and the environments are unbelievably vibrant. There's a lot to 'feel' here just by looking at skyboxes. It's indicative of good art design and adequate design on the technical side to support it. The art team is the MVP here.

The sound! Where to start? Jack Wall is absolutely fantastic, almost up to the level he was in the first game. He's at his best when he's laying down eerie music for the tense missions (Collector Ship, anybody?), buit he does a great job with handling the huge change in tone from the first game. Mass Effect 1 was carried by a super-techno, futuristic style soundtrick, whereas this one has touches of futurism but mostly just feels brooding and dirty. It fits the art direction of the game perfectly, and even a minimalist track like the droning that plays during the loading screen really does a fantastic job to impart and augment the overall 'feel' of this game, which is a big part of what I find so enticing about Mass Effect 2.

The writing is probably the games single strongest aspect. I don't mean to exaggerate, or to gush too much here, but there are some of the most well-written characters in any video game I've ever played. It's clear that Walters, Karpyshyn, and the rest of the writing staff were going for a Dirty Dozen, Wild West type feel with the characters and settings here, and they've succeeded in spades. There are a lot of characters that might even fit into a cliche, but the dialogue is so well-written and the voice acting is so superb that the game manages to skip that pothole and cruise along. Thane Krios, the spiritual, regreatful assassin, is a stand-out among a cast of solid personalities. His discussions with Shepard and his dealings with his son Kolyat are excellent. Garrus is far more fleshed out here than he was in the first game (in which I found his character to be disappointingly underdeveloped), and the writing here creates a bridge to his being so likeable in the third game. Legion, a character who arrives unfortunately late in the game, is another stellar twist and an amazingly well-written and impresses in unexpected ways. It's hard to go into detail without spoiling anything, but suffice it to say that his obsessive 'complex' is wholely unexpected and goes on to completely destroy any expectation I had when I initially learned of the characters presence in the game.

There are some pitfalls here, unfortunately, mostly in the form of Jacob Taylor. He always came off as completely unlikeable to me, though that's more a personal feeling and not a general criticism. I think he's a poor character simply because there's not really much there to dig into. He's got some father issues to deal with that feel crammed in mid-game and seem to hover around the outside of his character rather than fleshing out his core, like so many of the other characters side missions are intended to do.

Now that I've gushed over the good things, let's talk about some of the bad.

The game plays as if its half finished, particularly during combat. There's a nice idea and an adequate core design here, but it seems like it could have used far longer in the QA process than it actually had. The core mechanics of taking down the enemies shields/barriers, armor, and then health are really excellent. Each is weak to a different type of weapon, ammo, and power, so each encounter becomes a sort of puzzle where you're evaluating which enemy is the most threatening and thus must be dealt with first, and by using which power or weapon to do so. It's incredibly complex but relatively simple to learn, and getting through some of the more difficult encounters on hardcore or insanity difficulty is amazingly satisfying.

Sounds great, right? Unfortunately, while the game is at its best on the two hardest difficulty modes, it also suffers the most on those modes due to extremely buggy cover mechanics and unbelievably poor friendly AI. I really can't rag on the friendly AI enough. It's absolutely abysmal, and if you want that Insanity trophy you better be ready for some frustration. It's necessary to completely micomanage your allies by controlling where they're taking cover at all times. The problem with cover also manifests itself here, as there are many times when allies simply refuse to listen to you and wade out into enemy fire only to die immediately. It's so frustratingly idiotic that I find myself wondering how the game ever shipped in this fashion. It's a mess, and having to babysit your idiotic, suicidal squadmates really destroys what would have been an otherwise fantastic gameplay system. The general design is there, but the technical execution is utterly terrible and enough to make you bash your head against a wall. It's much more passable on Normal and Casual, but if you're gunning for Hardcore or Insanity, get ready for a headache.

The overall design of the game, despite these poorer aspects, is excellent. The episodic style of gameplay in which you're recruiting allies just feels right, and the game feels far more organized and direct than the first game ever did. On the harder difficulties you really get a sense of it being a race against time. You've got to plan out what missions you're doing at what time, because upgrades are incredibly important and if you find yourself trying to take on Horizon or the Collector Ship without the good ones, you can actually get completely stuck and be forced to start over. While this sounds frustrating, it actually does a good job to suck you into the situation that Shepard and the crew find themselves in. They've got to get all of this done, and quickly, because the Collectors are on the move and they aren't waiting for you. This episodic style is paced perfectly, and you never seem to experience any of the drag that you see in the first game when you get dropped onto the Citadel after Eden Prime only to find yourself immediately bogged down with a huge area to explore and dozens of sidequests to tackle. It does a far better job with making sure you never feel overwhelmed than the first game. It's open-ended enough without stranding you in a sea of objectives -- You've always got a handful of options of what to do next, and it's up to you to decide which seems to be most important.

All of the gameplay here comes to a head in a fantastic final act that sees everything you've done so far in the game build up to one massive conclusion. The suicide mission is truly excellent, and caps off a must-play game for everyone interested in RPGs.

Amazingly good game following the story of Commander Shepard.

Play this game if you want to know cool Characters, a good story and universe and a decently good third person shooter. This game is about the choices you make.

The choices you pick in the first game affects the second and so on. So get ME1 play through it with YOUR Shepard, then   import your Shepard from the first to the second and play it and so on. All the story DLC for the games are recommended.

BioWare had made a lot of improvements in the second game. While Mass Effect 1 was a great game, this sequel really just improves everything !

Mass Effect 3 [9.0/10] (endings [0/10])

Mass Effect should be a near masterpiece of a video game series. Sadly, the ending almost ruined the series. because no matter which ending you choose, all of the choices you've made in Mass Effect 1 & 2 leading up to the final moments mean nothing and have no effect on the final outcome.

reviewText: First playthrough...failed some loyalty missions, watched Yeoman Kelly (whom I was boning as a female Shepard) turn into genetic goo, made to feel like dirt by Dr. Chakwas, lost some of my favorite crew so defeating the Reaper was a bittersweet victory. reviewText: The Stuff of legends... Fans of Starwars Knights of the old republic 1&2, this is the game you've been missing. It may not satisfy the diehard Starwarsaphiles but as far as game mechanics, interactivestorytelling, cause and effect style consequences, and the whole play how you want, who you want, when you want, and where you want in whatever order you want to will keep you immersed and hold your attention for at minimum 3 play thru's. In fact, when you factor in acheivements, multiple (several) romances avenues, Perfect good outcome, Perfect bad outcome, Gaining max loyalty of your teammates, and all the DLC's (which depending on your moral values, are easily obtainable, and free) your unlikely to lose interest prior to a 3rd playthrough. Guides are mostly awesome, and there is a fix availible (easy to apply) to give you full xbox console controller support.  Lots of mods are availible also, but its already a perfect game so don't expect to use them until you've finished your first playthrough.\n\nAll in all people who played SWKOTR repeatedly will love this game, as far as the But its not starwars" crowd

reviewText:
After finishing Mass Effect 1 a couple of days ago, I was eager to start playing Mass Effect 2 as soon as possible. Expecting more of the same, I was in for a few unpleasant surprises. So much has changed that it almost feels like a different game.

CONTROLS:
The controls are so radically different from ME1 that it actually got me killed on several occasions. I felt like my arms had been cut off and then sewn back on backwards! I know that eventually I'll get used to the new controls but they still feel super weird.

WEAPONS:
Reloading? Seriously? Can't buy new weapons, only the blueprints? Really? While I'm happy that I don't have to manually customize every single weapon on every single squad member, this is a bit too simplistic.

MAP:
There was nothing wrong with the maps in ME1. The map in ME2 is hard to read and too colourful. It looks like somebody just resized all the locations to 20x10 pixels and made them into a map. What happened to the ability to add waypoints?

HUD:
Why am I able to light up" objects through walls? It's distracting. The colour and thickness of the rectangle make things easy to miss. In the first ME game everything stood out great when you placed the crosshairs over an item.

CHARACTER SKILLS:
What happened to all my skills from ME1? Puff! Disappeared into thin air! Now you only get five. Yay! Thank you
date:
Bioware!

PROFANITY:
I don't remember hearing much profanity in ME1. While I'm not against it per se

reviewText:
A must-have sequel to original Mass Effect. Not that it is particularly great - in my opinion, it doesn't measure up to its predecessor nor to the trilogy's finale - but it's a necessary part of the story and it's definitely worth playing.

The second part of ME franchise puts greater accent on squad interaction. In fact, you can get as much as a dozen companions, and missions related to their backstories occupy most of the game. It might be a turn-off for some, but if you felt immersed in the first Mass Effect, you should find most of those characters and missions quite enjoyable, at least during the first playthrough. I promise you're going to love some of your new squadmates, who will make you laugh and cry, and it seems that your old friends haven't forgotten about you after all.

The main storyline is consequently even shorter than in ME1, though with all the other assignments it shouldn't be a problem. One's for sure - I'm not going to spoil the climax, but it's as epic as the battle with the Sovereign. Mass Effect series didn't lose its scale and there are still moments that make you turn up the volume and sit at the edge of your seat. The ground battles have a whole new quality to them (finally Mass Effect has elements of a proper shooter - ducking behind cover and shooting seems more real and exciting than in the first part of the series), though perhaps you're going to miss the Mako.

A few words about the equipment system - it's much simplier than in the first game and I personally consider it an improvement. If you enjoyed comparing stats, shopping, and painstakingly equipping every single member of your squad, you might be disappointed, but if not, here's good news. The whole equipment system has been replaced with several items of weaponry, a few customizable elements of armor for Shepard, and a variety of upgrades giving bonuses for Commander or the whole squad. You may like it or not, but it's definitely easier to deal with. Leveling system has been simplified as well - maybe even too much - but it's now more intuitive, and it doesn't take 40 levels to get you the skill you want anymore.

My biggest pain with this game lies within DLC-s, which cost more than the game itself (especially when it's on sale), but when you finally play them, they seem essential to the story. It might be a pain in your wallet, but the sad truth is that some content has been apparently cut from the game and sold in separate bundles. Mass Effect 2 is still a fairly good game by itself, but it feels somehow incomplete without that additional content.

That said, it's still Mass Effect, and thus it's a part of one of the greatest stories I've been immersed in. Don't forget to check digital deluxe edition available here for the same price... and have fun!

reviewText:
don't expect a outstanding shooter/rpg, this game is carried solely by its characters.

most of the levels outside of towns are designed like tubes or arenas with the occasional branch which always lead back together at some point, exploring for hidden items is limited. the fighting/shooting is nothing to write home about. the majority of skills you can unlock aren't to exciting either.

biggest con are probEably the mini games most of them are fun for the first few times BUT they are HOPELESSLY overused, especialy mining/probing for minerals becomes a very annoying chore after the first couple of planets, expect to spend atleast half of your total game time just harvesting planets if you are the hoarding type of player.

once you reach the end of the game you realise you only needed a small fraction of all the minerals that you can mine to unlock all upgrades, perfect example for a artifical game-time extender.


the main story is ok but the thing that kept me playing till the end are the dialogues, facial expressions and overall very good design of every character, creature and even most of the enviorments and their individual storys that make this game-univers so believable and intersting.

reviewText:
A must-have sequel to original Mass Effect. Not that it is particularly great - in my opinion, it doesn't measure up to its predecessor nor to the trilogy's finale - but it's a necessary part of the story and it's definitely worth playing.

The second part of ME franchise puts greater accent on squad interaction. In fact, you can get as much as a dozen companions, and missions related to their backstories occupy most of the game. It might be a turn-off for some, but if you felt immersed in the first Mass Effect, you should find most of those characters and missions quite enjoyable, at least during the first playthrough. I promise you're going to love some of your new squadmates, who will make you laugh and cry, and it seems that your old friends haven't forgotten about you after all.

The main storyline is consequently even shorter than in ME1, though with all the other assignments it shouldn't be a problem. One's for sure - I'm not going to spoil the climax, but it's as epic as the battle with the Sovereign. Mass Effect series didn't lose its scale and there are still moments that make you turn up the volume and sit at the edge of your seat. The ground battles have a whole new quality to them (finally Mass Effect has elements of a proper shooter - ducking behind cover and shooting seems more real and exciting than in the first part of the series), though perhaps you're going to miss the Mako.

A few words about the equipment system - it's much simplier than in the first game and I personally consider it an improvement. If you enjoyed comparing stats, shopping, and painstakingly equipping every single member of your squad, you might be disappointed, but if not, here's good news. The whole equipment system has been replaced with several items of weaponry, a few customizable elements of armor for Shepard, and a variety of upgrades giving bonuses for Commander or the whole squad. You may like it or not, but it's definitely easier to deal with. Leveling system has been simplified as well - maybe even too much - but it's now more intuitive, and it doesn't take 40 levels to get you the skill you want anymore.

My biggest pain with this game lies within DLC-s, which cost more than the game itself (especially when it's on sale), but when you finally play them, they seem essential to the story. It might be a pain in your wallet, but the sad truth is that some content has been apparently cut from the game and sold in separate bundles. Mass Effect 2 is still a fairly good game by itself, but it feels somehow incomplete without that additional content.

That said, it's still Mass Effect, and thus it's a part of one of the greatest stories I've been immersed in. Don't forget to check digital deluxe edition available here for the same price... and have fun!

reviewText: Having just recently replayed Mass Effect 2 I was shocked at just how well everything has held up. People praise ME2 for being one of the greatest games made and it's hard to argue. Mass Effect 2 is a truly remarkable game and what makes it that way isn't any one aspect, but the interplay between all the systems that has allowed it to shine. Only by skillfully weaving the elements of combat, story, art and sound together did the men and women of BioWare create such a remarkable experience. But there's one additional system that has helped elevate Mass Effect 2 to such a timeless classic. The players. By adding our own personal stories to the tapestry already laid out by BioWare did each and everyone of us create their own indelible experiences that will always hold up to the test of time. Mass Effect 2 respects the player's choices and because of that it will ALWAYS be that good.

reviewText: This is a fantastic game. The gameplay is fun, and has a clean layout bar for all your biotics. There is alot of fun to be had. The story took me around 25 hours to complete, and it was epic from start to finish. The pacing of it is also really good. The share of time with the story and gameplay are near perfect, and Bioware definetly knew their strong points in the developement. The RPG factor of this game is also really well made, with dialogue options that progress into relationships and story, and an interesting karma system similar to SWTOR and Fallout: New Vegas that unlock more dialogue options. The graphics are pretty good too, but I'm not gonna go into detail about that since this is a 5 year old game. The sound design helps set the theme for a futuristic galaxy very well, and there are a few songs from the official soundtrack that I really like. Now... technical issues. The game crashed on me twice. I don't know why, but they did. Also one time, I was floating in the air walking around, which was hilarious until I found out couldn't get down. Luckily I could just load the previous autosave. Seriously though, this is still a fantastic game. There's a HUGE galaxy to explore, and a ton of planets to visit or even mine resources from. Even when you finish the storyline and feel those chills from that EPIC ending mission, you can still continue travelling around the Milky Way completing sidequests. Not only is Mass Effect 2 a fantastic game, but it is now one of the best games I have ever played.

reviewText: Okay, this is the best game i have ever played in my life. It has such an awesome story and characters. All of the things you do, all the thing you say matter. Its not just some random game you can play and don`t care about anything, you get attached to your crew and story by itself feels deep and inspiring. The Music in Mass Effect is utterly awe inspiring. It's music that any true Mass Effect fan has felt empowered by, saddened by, inspired by, and moved by. Even on it's own, out of context of the three absolutely stunning games, it always provokes emotion from me. Mass Effect is the greatest RPG series of all time, and it's OST more than lives up to the story and experience. When it came to the end, when everything came down to the wire, everything that you did in the game came out. You put everything on the line, everything you had, and through sheer willpower, and sacrifice, and tremendous effort, YOU did it. Your team. You. You saw in detail how every choice you made in the game came into play in that final half hour of the game. If you failed, it wasn't some planet you'd never seen, or countless random soldiers you didn't care about, it was your teammates that you'd fought with for hours and hours of gametime, characters you'd built relationships with and honestly come to see as friends. The Suicide Mission is one of the best end-levels in history. The fact that you choose your teammates for each task and aren't told which one is clearly the best made it feel so immersive. You actually had to know them, not just take them for missions as if they are dumb robots. The Mass Effect Trilogy (Mass Effect 2 in particular) is not just one of the great video games ever created, but it's also one of the greatest works of Sci-Fi ever

reviewText: Just finished my second playthrough of 1 thru 3, with a couple of the DLCs installed and the extended cut ending. Believe the positive reviews; this game will stay with you! This is the only experience since the original Deus Ex that has had me invested this way. The three instalments each play slightly differently, but all are worth every penny, especially now! IMHO all three are required, in the right order, for the full story to be appreciated, and to witness the character relationships in their maturity.\nIncredibly well written, countless inter-related stories and subplots, NPCs that really do come to life through the script, top notch voice acting, and how you choose to interact with them (or not!). Excellent character graphics and animation, numerous interactive cut-scenes, action, exploration, intimacy...\nI can't recommend this highly enough! The only real problem with the Mass Effect series is what to play afterwards without it feeling bland by comparison!

reviewText: The direct sequel to the blockbusting science fiction RPG hit by Bioware, Mass Effect 2 picks up on and improves everything that made ME1 so memorable.\nJust like the first game, Mass Effect 2 has a very high immersion factor thanks to givin the player every opportunity to step into the shoes of the now legendary Commander Shepard, a completely customizeable protagonist in whom the player can all but become the savior or the scourge of the galaxy. Thanks to the save-file transfer system, all the major and even a few minor choices the player made in the first game will carry over into this game and change how the galactic community views you and the human race.\nThe story has evolved quite a bit and at this point in the series is beginning to unfold into something grand and sinister, upon learning that your quarry from the previous game was nothing more than a mindless puppet being used by an even greater threat, the Commander has had difficulty convincing the council of this looming presence (ah yes, reapers") and is instead being sent out to clean out the remaining synthetic soldiers used by Saren. Until a massive twist in the form of what looks suspiciously like a floating space turd attacks your ship and kills you in the process

reviewText: Mass Effect 2 is a cinematic, story driven game with superb character development, sound and fun gameplay, and an explorative galaxy to boot. As Commander Shepard, you can create your own character, modify how they look, choose their class of biotics and combat tactics, as well as shape your own personal view on the galaxy, either being a kind and forgiving Paragon, or a guns blazing no bull Renegade. As previously mentioned, the characters (which there are plenty of, more if you count DLC from the Deluxe Edition) and they all have great story arcs. The voice acting is superb by both Shepards, male and female. It has expansive codex's to inform those if you havn't played the first game, which you should definitely do as the saves carry over between the games. This is a 10/10 for me, and easily one of my favourite games of all time.

reviewText:
The first thing you notice about this sequel to Space Marine Inventory Manager 2007 is the complete lack of having to manage your space marine's inventory, which oddly enough improves the game no end!

You've played the first Mass Effect, right? If so, you know the drill. ME2 delivers more of the good stuff, refines or removes the not-so-good stuff, gives you prettier visuals, etc. BioWare/EA once again test the patience of PC gamers around the world by not bothering to implement gamepad support and offering a DLC purchasing system so terrible that you'll think twice about throwing money their way.

But, despite all of that, ME2 remains one of the most impressive action RPGs of the past decade, delivering an interesting gallery of characters, a better-than-average script and art design that puts many blockbuster sci-fi movies to shame.

reviewText:
A highly anticipated sequal to the genre-defining excellence of Mass Effect, we have Mass Effect 2. I may be some filthy casual with a love for choices, RPGs, and hot pixelated women - but damn it, this is my review!

Ahem.

Mass Effect 2 continues where Mass Effect left off, leaving Shepard in a rough position between those who are hesitant to believe his claims and that of a rise in human political power. Taking things into his own hands, Shepard is required to find a new crew - and embark on a mission that could very well be his last.

The gameplay is streamlined from the previous, enjoyable, though with its own shortcomings. The shooting is perhaps a bit more fine tuned, not that the first really warranted much issue. The addition of ammunition makes for a more traditional shooter feel, which I didn't mind - seeing as how it's explained in the very first loading screen (though I have a couple questions). The only downside really is the large departure from Abilities in place of Shooting. Classes sucha s the Sentinel and the [Insert other Tech class here that isn't the stealth class] feels a bit unloved, and even Vanguard seems to have been lacking its zeal.

The soldier and the stealth class lead in this game, it seems - given their weapon-natures and ability to dish out the love with many of them. Playing as a Vanguard through all three games, ME2 seemed to have the least options for my progression.

Having said that, I'm a sucker for character development, and I really appreciated the handling of many of the Mass Effect characters. Some have a traditional 'you helped me, I love you know' mentality - whereas others feel more real. Jack seems to really soften, though I've never gone through with a romance with her. The relationship you can build with one of the previous crewmates is rewarding as she didn't just pounce on you in the first game after you punched your locker in anger for saying nice things to her. She has a developed character, and I doubt my restraint in using the name really fools anyone.

I'd try to continue, but I've typed enough. Buy the game, play it. If you hate it, damn son - that's hard. If you love it, then we probably share some opinions on Sci-Fi and RPGs.

Was it a worthy sequel to ME1? I'd say so. It may focus more on action, so if that makes it Gears of Halo, then I guess it's a good thing I never saw it that way. The exploration is reduced in favor of a more freeform progression with a number of characters and personal options. If I had to choose, I'd say ME2 was probably my least favorite installment in the entire series - however, that's hardly an insult.

(Yes, ME3 was a fantastic game - minus the last six minutes or so of the game. But my opinion on the need for the Dark Energy ending is an entire matter entirely.)
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is epic. After you complete it, you feel like having saved the galaxy, which you actually do in this game.

The first ME had a great story, but everything else was bad or mediocre. ME2 has fixed all the flaws of its predecessor. So, what you get, is almost a perfect game.

Specific improvements:

- Graphics and textures: a wider variety
- Galaxy map: easier navigation, there are mission marks, so you don't have to read your journal, to know where you should be going
- Mining: actually makes sense in this game, as you gather resources for your upgrades; although, sometimes it feels like overkill
- More squad members to choose from
- More action, the dialogues are more compact
- Better battle system, though it's still not completely convenient to control your squad members
- More weapons, no floating when zoomed
- Mako is gone – yes! – hated that thing
- Better interface

The only flaw this game has, is occasional camera behaviour problems, e.g., in the mission where husks are running into you in narrow cave corridors, there are problems with FOV and camera rotation.

Grenades would have been useful, but there aren't any.

My overall rating:

9/10

reviewText:
Zaeed: One of the most powerful gang leaders in the galaxy, until he was betrayed.
Legion: Completely unique hacker robot, envoy for a people exiled who want to belong.
Jack: Experimented on to make her one of the most powerful biotics to exist. They weren't fun experiments. She's not happy.
Grunt: He's basically indestructible, and really, really likes shooting things. He's also an adolescent, so that's fun.
Jacob: Trained in the military, he's a straight up soldier. A reliable guy to have covering your back.
Tali: A fragile-looking small girl in an isolation suit. She's an expert at hacking from a distance. Also, shotgunning enemies in the face.
Garrus: He's a crack shot who led a team of freedom fighters against a series of gangs until he as the only one left. He also quite enjoys calibrations.
Thane: An expert assassin with a terminal disease and a life of wrongs to right in the time he has left.
Samara: Sworn an oath to uphold justice, she's spent hundreds of years hunting down criminals and her very deadly daughters.
Kasumi: Expert thief, she's stolen things that were completely impossible to steal on numerous occasions. You've never heard of her. She likes it that way.
Mordin: He is the very model of a scientist salarian. He has done things in his life that he knows were absolutely necessary, but that doesn't mean he won`t try to fix any damage he's caused.

Then there's Miranda. She's genetically engineered to be perfect in every way, and it makes her life SO HARD. Oh no

reviewText:
Like it's predecessor, Mass Effect 2 does not dissapoint with it's stellar storyline and delivery. Top tier voice actors, and simply the *best* storyline out of *any* RPG game out on console and PC.

ME2 improves on everything about ME1. Giving the game a more fast paced feel to it. They cut back a tad on the RPG aspect, but not in a bad way at all.

I reccomend the entire Mass Effect series. 1-3. For any RPG gamer who appreciates a game with an excellent story, interactive characters, and just good ol' shooting fun-- the Mass Effect series is the perfect fusion of the two, for you to receive optimal enjoyment.

reviewText: Mass Effect 2 is an amazing action-rpg with great third person shooting mechanics.  The combat is very fun but not what makes Mass Effect so unforgettable.  The highlight is the characters, the way you interact with them, and the choices you make.  The characters are fully fleshed out and many of the game's missions are dedicated to gaining your allies' loyalty and learning more about them.  The ways you interact with them and decisions you make in the game, or have made in Mass Effect 1, have consequences both grand and subtle.  They combine to make the game one of the most personalized gaming experiences out there.\nMany triple A games aim to deliver an epic experience, and I won't claim that they fail.  But Mass Effect 2 is probably the most epic game I am familiar with.  Its epicness cannot be overstated and in fact its epicness is quantitatively thrice as large as the epicness of other triple A games whose epicness is the main selling point.  Yet despite the incredible epicness of Mass Effect 2 (and I am in no way discrediting the power of epicness), it doesn't neglect to add incredible depth to its characters and choices.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Mass Effect 2 had a lot to live up to, and wow did it fail. At first.

The base game for Mass Effect 2 was devoid of almost everything that made the original great. Each mission was nothing more than killing some guys with no option to do anything else. Inventory management was completely removed from the game and the gameplay became that of a shooter - choose mission, go to instance, kill guys, cutscene.

But, - and this is a big but - the DLC does a lot to fix this game. Where the base game was devoid of anything but the main mission, the DLC adds much-needed hand-crafted content - and just enough for me to recommend this game (with DLC).

reviewText: Mass Effect 2 is a stunning and unforgettable experience! This franchise has brought me to emotional high points (yes, I have shed manly tears) multiple times; the characterization is simply incredible! You actually feel like your squad members are real people that you care for and not some mindless husks, devoid of any personality (I'm looking at you Skyrim).\n\nI know, it's ironic to say that this is possibly my favorite game ever, and be part of an EA-protesting group. However, I am completely sincere and hold nothing back: this game is nothing short of a masterpiece. It should definitely be on your bucket list and also merits multiple playthroughs. Pick it up as soon as you can, you won't regret a thing!

reviewText: I have not finished playing Mass Effect 2, however I applaud it and its predecessor for its creative use of modern physics to penetrate, if only slightly, the vast distances that lie between stars. Mass Effect 2 also adds more realistic flight sequences, as one has to calculate how much fuel will get them to their destination, acknowledging that fuel is, in fact, a finite resource. However, it does to some extent ignore Newton's first law in that one slows to a halt the minute the ship ceases to accelerate, however, there are worse gripes to be had about a video game than It follows Aristotelian physics
date: as Aristotle essentially laid the groundwork for all modern thought.\n\nOne of my favorite things to do as Commander Shepard was to probe undiscovered worlds, as this was something that I did in real life with the Voyager Probes. However, I doubt that these probes contained anything like the Golden Record that we put together, as First Contact has already been established in the Mass Effect universe.

reviewText: Mass Effect, the game where have no idea which dialouge choices affect the story and which ones are just for show. Missing these important game-changing dialogue can really change the outcome of your gameplay, so watch out! This is the major selling point for me. Other than the great squad-based combat, Mass Effect 2 has a great, immersive story with interesting characters who each have their own unique history and past. The atmosphere is unique and the overall univerese is just so diverse and fleshed out. The conflict is great and the choices that have to be made are crucial and important. So, if you're looking for a game with a great story, a colorful cast of characters, strategic combat and crucial choices, then Mass Effect is the game for you!!!\n\n-Yumi

reviewText: Mass Effect 2 adds another chapter in the Mass Effect trilogy, and it does so pretty damn well. It's been argued this game has the best plot out of the three games, and I'd say that's a fair statement. They really liven it up compared to the first Mass Effect. That being said, you'd be doing yourself a great disservice if you didn't play the first game before this one; you won't understand what ANYONE is saying. More importantly, you'll be missing out on crafting your very own story, making those important decisions in ME1, and that's what really stands out about this series. The gameplay is more refined, and smoother than the first, but dumbed down. A lot of the RPG'ness is sucked out of this one, which some people like. You can't customize your weapons or armor as extensively as you could like in one, but it isn't a complete loss; the game is still utterly fantastic and worth your time. All in all, this is an important step in the story of Commander Shepard, and until you beat it, you'll be absorbed.

reviewText: I give this game a recommendation *ONLY* for the diverse sci-fi tapestry that forms the background to a shallow storyline.  It is obvious the time and energy that went into the computer entrie surrounding the alien races, their homeworlds their history and even their prejudices FAR outweighed the time and energy spent on other things. Not to mention the energy spent on making the communities you encounter seem vibrant and alive.\n\nThat being said there is ALOT of regurgitation from KOTOR especially the second.  When I first watched the Ebon Hawk... errr I mean the Normandy" land on Omega my jaw dropped (the whole scene
recommended: was ripped from KOTOR 2).  Till I realized that ME2 was made by Bioware. Still if video game developers were more like writers half of the cutscenes and characters would come with a disclaimer in the corner *Reproduced From An Earlier Work*.  These things mostly lead to loud guffaws from me as I watched something that seemed so unnervingly similar to somthing I had seen before...... felt like I was playing a KOTOR 3 that lost the rights to use the Star Wars I.P.\n\nThe other thing about Mass Effect is the constant similarity to Star Trek.  The whole thing with Shepard falling onto a planet
hoursPlayed:
project Lazarus (sounding like a nod to Project Genesis from "The Search for Spock") even the Geth being ideologically near identical to the BORG.

Two major negatives are the semi-dependance on ownership of the first Mass Effect to get crew members and certain side quests (nothing major really just unfortunate to me) and the fact that I found this in the RPG genre when really it's not.

Good for a nice sci-fi vacation but don't expect it to break much from the KOTOR mold that it was obviously pressed from."

reviewText: An absolutely beautiful game that ran well even on my old PC, despite such beautiful graphics.\n\nIn combat you control a squad of 2 other people, from a pool of recruitable companions who have their own strengths and backstories. The combat is basically an FPS game with some magic" abilities in the form of biotics and tech
date: which can be learned by companions by leveling up and spending talent points.\n\nThe graphics are so great
recommended: that I did not want to use any of the free armor in the deluxe edition
hoursPlayed:
because they cover Shepard's face and ruined the immersion.
The sounds of the game are also great. The disco music of the first night club that you go to really sounds disco-ish.
The cut scenes and voiced conversations are great. I actually look forward to talking to people because the conversations are interesting.
The main story and the mini-stories of your party members are very well done.

The game makes you feel like you are in a sci-fi movie. It is a "sensory overload" to your eyes an"

reviewText: How do you describe a game that is so extraordinary as Mass Effect 2? Where do you begin? With the superb graphics, that stand with the best today? Do you go with the gameplay that feels a thousand times more polished than the first with absolutely tons of available sidequests as well as Downloadable content? Maybe with the fact that this is the first story game that has allowed a player to carry over player-made decisions onto another game, and with this comes a promise that the character you crafted to YOUR expectations would be waiting for you in this story. (That alone is something that gamers like myself have been waiting years for.) And don't even get me started on the story and where the team at Bioware is taking this series. Not only are your character relationships you made in ME1 still intact, but now they have new and truly exciting avenues that they can take. This is doubly true for the Lair of The Shadow Broker DLC with character Liara T'soni. (Highly recommended, along with all the other DLC) Then there is Shephard. The hero who has a bit more personality than before, is forged through player decisions that can alter the state of your party dramatically. And forging him or her is another matter altogether. How exactly do you craft a character who is the most important human in the galaxy? And more, a character who knows it? These elements are sheer brilliance and the amazing experience gifted to us in the first is grossly intensified. The action feels real and livid. The romantic stories feel romantic (particularly with Garrus, Thane, Jack and Tali Zorah, who seem the slightly less than obvious choices) And the music (yes, I'm yet again, going into the music) composed by Jack Wall fits the situations of the game even better than the first entry. Some take issue with the mining and doorlock minigames because of their repetitive nature. To me, it is small potatoes considering the rest of the experience. By the end, you feel the weight of your decisions and their consequences on your shoulders, be they good or bad. The brilliant thing, though, is that you've felt this all along.\n\n10/10

reviewText:
I feel that comparisions to the original game is necessary when writing a review for Mass Effect 2, so here it goes:

1. Like Mass Effect, Mass Effect 2 is a story-rich 3rd-person FPS where you play as Commander Sheperd. However, the story was not as captivating as ME1 and it seemed that I spent more time assembling and gaining the loyalty of my crew than on the main campaign, which in retrospect was pretty short and straightforward.

2. The combat system was an improvement from ME1, where it was much easier to utilise abilities (both yours and your squad's) by binding them to the numerical keys. However, combat got really repetitive after a while. The hacking/ bypassing system was also an improvement, although mostly unnecessary and also repetitive.

3. Anyone who played the original game would remember the dreadfully long elevator rides. Thankfully, ME2 had smoother transitioning and also higher quality cut-scenes which were very enjoyable.

4. Like in ME1, it was possible to flirt/ develop relationships with a number of crewmates, although you would have to complete your target's loyalty quest before you could express interest. However, I was disappointed when Liara (ME1 character) could not be recruited into my squad, even though she did make an appearance in the game.

I gave ME1 a rating of 9.5/10 only because of the elevator rides. While ME2 was a good game, it seemed to be lacking in story and also its descent into repetitiveness.

8.5/10

reviewText:
Mass Effect 2 is a great sequel to an equally impressive game. While I do believe that this second installment is a bit over-praised, it is still an incredible game that builds on the successes of its predecessor very well.

I do believe that most components of the combat system are improved. The only small detail that I don't personally enjoy is a matter of personal preference and doesn't really bother me, as it is present in most shooters anyways. The visuals are obviously much more impressive as well and make an impact on immersion in this case. Overall, the gameplay mechanics have been vastly improved as far as fluidity and functionality.

What truly matters when evaluating this title, however, is the narrative and the ability of the game to make you care about its characters and its stories. While I personally believe that the first Mass Effect did a better job of making the player care about each and every character and his or her story, Mass Effect 2 still retains the important features that characterize the NPCs and make the story memorable and cannot be criticized for a lack of story; my personal opinion shouldn't have an impact on the validity and inspiration of the title. The fundamental RPG elements of Mass Effect 2 make it stand above virtually any other RPG on the market today.

Mass Effect 2 is an amazing game and is undoubtedly a must-own title.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: I used to think Mass Effect 1 was the best in the series, and used to be very biased toward it. After recently playing through Mass Effect 2 though, I have to say that I think this one is the best in the series. While I do miss a lot of the RPG aspects that Mass Effect 1 offered, and were removed from Mass Effect 2, I think the overall improvements to Mass Effect 2 overshadow that. The TPS aspects are way more solid, and feel a lot tighter. They also added an ammo system to the game and removed the heat aspect. While I did enjoy the heat aspect of Mass Effect 1, and figuring out ways to manage it, the ammo system works out in the end. I may also be one of the only ones that actually enjoyed using the Mako, but even though it was replaced in this game with a scan type of thing on planets, it makes it a lot more streamlined. Overall, the story and storytelling is awesome in Mass Effect 2. Everything in Mass Effect 2 is more streamlined, and feels a lot more solid compared to Mass Effect 1. It's a great game, and I definitely recommend it to fans of Mass Effect 1, or just fans of deep storylines, and Shooter/RPG fans.

reviewText:
Pre-review Note: Mass Effect 3 completes the Mass Effect trilogy but isn't available on Steam. I highly recommend purchasing this for Origin - it's an excellent game and an epic conclusion to the series.


Mass Effect 2:

Positives:

+ Another amazing, story-driven game by Bioware, where your decisions impact the way in which others view you and how the plotline develops. Become a paragon or renegade through your choices in quests.
+ New locations to explore, each filled with numerous side missions and content relevant to the main narrative.
+ Interesting characters (won't add any spoilers), each with their own personal quest lines.
+ New range of weapons and upgrades, you can even reinforce the Normandy with state of the art equipment.
+ Great graphics, a massive step up from the original title.
+ The game has been streamlined, making it more sleak and professional in appearance compared to the first entry in the trilogy.

Negatives:

- Although Mass Effect 2 looks a lot more refined and stylish than its predecessor, it comes at the expensive of its RPG characteristics. Leveling has been dumbed down a bit, but still plays a role in the game (thankfully).

Overall Score: 9/10

Mass Effect 2 is an incredible RPG shooter which is very fun, keeps your attention and attaches you to characters through great storytelling. Definitely don't miss out on this game and pick it up on sale.

reviewText: Mass Effect 2 adds another chapter in the Mass Effect trilogy, and it does so pretty damn well. It's been argued this game has the best plot out of the three games, and I'd say that's a fair statement. They really liven it up compared to the first Mass Effect. That being said, you'd be doing yourself a great disservice if you didn't play the first game before this one; you won't understand what ANYONE is saying. More importantly, you'll be missing out on crafting your very own story, making those important decisions in ME1, and that's what really stands out about this series. The gameplay is more refined, and smoother than the first, but dumbed down. A lot of the RPG'ness is sucked out of this one, which some people like. You can't customize your weapons or armor as extensively as you could like in one, but it isn't a complete loss; the game is still utterly fantastic and worth your time. All in all, this is an important step in the story of Commander Shepard, and until you beat it, you'll be absorbed.

reviewText:
I don't understand why would anyone check the user reviews of this game. Dude, this game is one of the best games out there. The Mass Effect trilogy is, in my book, the best one in the entire gaming history. By far. I don't care what anyone have to say about the third game. These games made me cry like a little b*tch.
Well, let's see:
PROS: Amazing and breathtaking prologue (Trust me on that one) and an incredible story.
Old and new companions. Each one with an amazing back story that will make you love them.
Customizable armor.
Impressive armory with new awesome weapons.
The perfect mix between RPG and TPS.
The best game of the trilogy (And I'm not saying that the other two are bad at all).
Biotics and powers are much better than ME1.
Of course, all the choices you made in ME1 will be crucial in this game and you will continue your story depending on what you did in the previous game.CONS:
Downloadable Content is not included in this version of the game and it's incredibly expensive to buy through BioWare Store, sadly (Story DLC's like Kasumi's Stolen Memories, Project Overlord, Arrival).
Exploring the galaxy and probing for resources can be a little tiring.
If you want to enjoy the game even more, play it on Insanity difficulty.

reviewText: I have not played Mass Effect 1- but I still found this game to be amazing. The characters, the story, the gameplay - it is pure fun. The cover-based squad combat works great. The downsides to this game are that you have very limited options when it comes to choosing weapons- there is often one clear weapon to choose over another when picking a shotgun, pistol, SMG, etc. Also, the game seems to get into the end-game very quickly- just when you think you're just coming together as a team, you hit the last level. Finally, it seems that choosing different squadmates has a very small impact on gameplay- it makes little difference who I choose to bring with me. They all do about the same amount of damage- the only thing that changes are your abilities, which means that teammates with the more useful abilities should ALWAYS be chosen over those that don't have useful abilities. Other than this, everything about the game (except for the mining mini-game. Don't get me started on that) is phenomenal- there is a universe here that is meant to be explored, and boy is it fun.

reviewText: Mass Effect, the game where have no idea which dialouge choices affect the story and which ones are just for show. Missing these important game-changing dialogue can really change the outcome of your gameplay, so watch out! This is the major selling point for me. Other than the great squad-based combat, Mass Effect 2 has a great, immersive story with interesting characters who each have their own unique history and past. The atmosphere is unique and the overall univerese is just so diverse and fleshed out. The conflict is great and the choices that have to be made are crucial and important. So, if you're looking for a game with a great story, a colorful cast of characters, strategic combat and crucial choices, then Mass Effect is the game for you!!!\n\n-Yumi

reviewText: This is one of my favorite games of all time. The story and characters were great and so was the gameplay. I liked that you had to assemble your team and improve them in order for you and your team to survive the final mission. This has to be my favorite game in the Mass Effect trilogy. I would recommend playing all 3 of these games in order and importing your save each time if you really want to enjoy this. Mass Effect 2, like the rest of the trilogy, has great replay value and you can easily play it for hours. BioWare games always have a great story and Mass Effect 2 is no exception. I had previously owned all 3 of these games on PS3 but had to buy them again for the PC because they are just so good. Mass Effect was the first RPG I had really played and since then I have gone on to enjoy others. I would strongly recommend starting here if you are used to action games and want tho get into RPGs or just enjoy sci-fi. I would also recommend this to any RPG fan because it is a great RPG with an immersive sci-fi universe with an interesting backstory and memorable characters.

reviewText: I don't like Mass Effect! Something about it turns me off, and I can't say whether the brunt of it is the bland sci-fi that nerds love or the ♥♥♥♥ing lame cover shooting mechanic. But what do I know, because I sat through the entire ♥♥♥♥ing thing and played it without quitting, so it's doing SOMETHING right. This iteration has that weird alien dude called Mordin (probably the only character I've ever liked), boring planet probing for resources instead of boring lore-filled vehicle sections (you have to collect most of the resources for the best toys, so pucker up), more cover shooting, and while it fails to be compelling... well, I sat through the entire thing. So it's doing something right. Good ambience, maybe? ♥♥♥♥ if I know, I'm not playing this again or Mass Effect 3 under threat of being smothered into unconsciousness by boring gameplay. You figure out what it is.

reviewText:
(Redone recommendation from scratch)
The squel to Mass Effect (1)!

In the sequel to Mass Effect (1) you will continue to play as Shepard from the first game (The same character if you imported him or her) on a new quest.

This time around though you will notice something almost immediately; Combat has changed!
Now the game has changed around more to a cover based shooter compared to what the first game was (I mean, there WERE some cover based shooting in the first, but now its radically different) and also you are now using limited ammunition.

Some people welcomed this change, some didn't. I personally am still on the fence about the changes to combat.

But its quicker, more actionny than ever. Also you can only use one power at once since other powers will be put on cooldown once you activate a power (In the first game you could maybe use 8 powers at once but had maybe a minuter cooldown).

The question is though, is it fun? Oh hell yes, the combat is fun. It also makes it more interesting trying other classes and trying out different choices in the first game in order to see what will change in the second game.

Storytime eh? Yeah yeah.
This time Shepard will be summoned by the corporation Cerberus" and is tasked to find out why an alien race called the "Collectors" are kidnapping humans
date:
so its up to you to find a new crew on you voyage amongst the stars and find out the grim truth about the kidnapping of humans...

One thing is sure; this game is more grim than the first and third game. No dance on flowers here.

While the story to me is not good as the first but the interactions with the crew and characters keeps this game going. They also cut out the unnecessarily exploration bits (Love it or hate it) and major loot collecting has been removed entirely (Although you can do some cool research/upgrades in your lab).

**And yes
recommended: i need to put this into here; Mass Effect 3 mini-review!**\nMass Effect 3 is the last game in the Mass Effect Trilogy. While the combat was the best out of the three (According to me)
hoursPlayed: the story took a major backlash thanks to the ending.\n\nBut
voteText: while the ending in the third game is absolotely horrible i can tell you one thing; The journey is a good one.\n\nThe sad truth though is that if you want to play Mass Effect 3 you have to buy it elsewhere than on Steam..."

reviewText:
10/10.

Hands down the best CRPG I've played. Above and beyond Mass Effect 1. Buy it if you enjoy science fiction and engrossing stories!

Yes, there's more action in Mass Effect's sequel, but with the better streamlined skill trees and in-combat control, it ties in very nicely with the overarching milieu's story and lore. And it's the story that really seals the deal here. The persistent characters, the evolution of your story and consequences from choices (arguably cosmetic, they still feel tangible to me),

They took everything that worked in Mass Effect 1, pared off what didn't, and made it better. It's extremely seldom that sequels are better than the originals, but Mass Effect proves exceptions do occur.

Not to be left out and this isn't intended to TMI or unncessary but merely an endorsement -- this is the second game I've played (ME1 being the first) that allows for romances that I actually participated in and enjoyed. (Note to self: I seem to play a lot of women that enjoy the company of women. Who knew?)

reviewText: The gameplay is little bit different than the first Mass Effect but the storyline just as good. Many new interesting NPCs in addition to recurring characters from the first game. The missions are more interesting than the previous series because the levels are better defined compared to ME 1 where the interior of any building looks very similar.There is wider selection of squad members so you can employ many different tactics according to a mission's need. The squad members also have unique personalities and history that they can share with you, given you spend some time to talk to them. The loyalty missions, squad members confrontation with each other and romance really adds flavour to the game. Squad members can die in the final mission (dubbed as the Suicide Mission) resulting from failing to secure their loyalty, not making ship upgardes or choosing non-ideal person for a task in the mission. This forces the player to carefully plan and prepares for the mission. The were so many different way the game progress and ends, even the main character may be killed in the suicide mission. This gives the game a very high replay value and the player did get a bonus to the character and resources should we choose start a new game after finishing one.\n\nOverall, Mass Effect 2 is a story rich game that continues the greatness of the first game. If you want to play the game, I suggest you finish ME1 first and carry forward your character into this game. Forget about wikis and walkthrough (except when you completely stuck of course) and just follow your heart and be yourself when making decision throughout the game and you will find out the Commander Shepard you're playing really reflects the person you are (Paragon and Renegade choices). You always can play it again later if you want to experience another options that you missed before, or choosing different character to romance or whatever different options the game can offer. But remember, the outcome of the decisions can be carried to Mass Effect 3. For score, I'm giving ME2 a solid 9/10

reviewText:
9/10

This series is so far the best series I have ever played.  The characters have depth, the graphics are amazing, and the story engulfs you.  Importing your player and their decisions from the first Mass Effect really helps you connect with the characters and their choices.  I felt a loyalty to my crew that I haven't felt since Cortana in the first 3 Halos, yet I am even more attached to these characters!  I haven't felt this emotionally moved since watching Doms tragic tale from the Gears of War series.  This game is a masterpiece.

Pro: Immersive story (take the best story you've ever heard/read and coat it in gold, dip it in diamond, and slap your arch
nemesis with it).
Lots of side missions to keep you busy (not too many that it gets boring).
Fantastic character development.
Your choices actually make a difference in character's lives (you will literally make life or death decisions).

Con: Changing of the skill point tree (less options).
Ammo is now required (spent a lot of time making sure I had picked up all the ammo I could).
Removal of loot (although the weapons they give you almost makes up for this).

reviewText: Very nearly the full kilo\n\nI enjoyed Mass Effect 1 but was only able to give it 3/5 due to some pretty annoying flaws. I’m glad to say that most of those flaws have been eradicated in ME2. Gone are the endless slow elevator rides. Gone are the tedious, bouncy buggy rides on dull, lifeless planets. And gone is the ridiculously complex HUD. What hasn’t changed are its strong points, which remain in the storyline and RPG elements. Once again there is a detailed and compelling story along with many side plots and missions, which are more diverse and creative than those in ME1. The voice acting is excellent throughout as are the character models and animations, which are fluid and naturalistic. Graphically it’s very good for a four-year-old game, although there’s little in the way of physics, which is a shame. The combat has also improved, although it remains rather clunky and lacklustre compared to other games. The Mass Effect franchise is clearly about providing a rich and developed universe in which to place the player and to give that player a full-bodied RPG experience peppered with combat and action along the way. And in this respect ME2 really delivers. If not for the so-so combat I would have given it 5/5, but as it is I give it 4/5.

reviewText: Mass Effect 2 is a huge improvement over Mass Effect 1. It's adapted to appeal to a wide audience of gamers while still bringing the charm of Bioware's old-school RPGs. While Mass Effect 1 (in my opinion) feels like it could have been more if the studio had more time or budget to fully develop the different worlds which could be explored, Mass Effect 2 feels complete and gives the player satisfaction in the limits of the game. Mass Effect 2 marks an important transition of Bioware from KOTOR-esque DnD storytelling (which brought Bioware to the living room) to the new era of cinematic gameplay which can be enjoyed by anyone.\n\nTL;DR: This is the game EA wanted when they bought Bioware.

reviewText:
WOW!

Story:
Let me start off by saying that this was the first Mass Effect I've ever played(Yes, I regret not buying ME1), it was simply beautiful in so many ways! I've seen other reviews for this game, and I gotta say - It actually is completely story-driven. Sure, there is gameplay, but mostly cutscenes, and that was suited well for this game. The optional character progression in Loyalty Missions" provide extra play time
date: getting to know the people you recruit
recommended: gaining their trust & their respect. All in all
hoursPlayed:
the story takes turns & provides new enemies to come in contact with.

I love the electric-orchestral vibes Mass Effect 2 brings to the table with its soundtrack! Every soundtrack definitely fits the mood for what's happening in that current situation

reviewText:
A truly amazing game. 10/10 in my honest and truthful opinion. In terms of story, customization, game play, innovation with story and characters personality. Everything you do can affect the gameplay, every relationship, every bad or good action.

Travel to neighboring galaxies. Harvest resources from planets. Find activity on planets and enter their atmosphere and carry out missions...Invasions on the planets.

If you buy Mass Effect 1 you can transfer your character from the first game to this game. Or you can create a new one. I Personally love Mass Effect 2 over all the others.

In short... I recommend this game. It is nearly flawless in all aspects of a game. $20 is nothing to pay for this game and on a steam sale it's even more worth it.

reviewText:
(Redone recommendation from scratch)
The squel to Mass Effect (1)!

In the sequel to Mass Effect (1) you will continue to play as Shepard from the first game (The same character if you imported him or her) on a new quest.

This time around though you will notice something almost immediately; Combat has changed!
Now the game has changed around more to a cover based shooter compared to what the first game was (I mean, there WERE some cover based shooting in the first, but now its radically different) and also you are now using limited ammunition.

Some people welcomed this change, some didn't. I personally am still on the fence about the changes to combat.

But its quicker, more actionny than ever. Also you can only use one power at once since other powers will be put on cooldown once you activate a power (In the first game you could maybe use 8 powers at once but had maybe a minuter cooldown).

The question is though, is it fun? Oh hell yes, the combat is fun. It also makes it more interesting trying other classes and trying out different choices in the first game in order to see what will change in the second game.

Storytime eh? Yeah yeah.
This time Shepard will be summoned by the corporation Cerberus" and is tasked to find out why an alien race called the "Collectors" are kidnapping humans
date:
so its up to you to find a new crew on you voyage amongst the stars and find out the grim truth about the kidnapping of humans...

One thing is sure; this game is more grim than the first and third game. No dance on flowers here.

While the story to me is not good as the first but the interactions with the crew and characters keeps this game going. They also cut out the unnecessarily exploration bits (Love it or hate it) and major loot collecting has been removed entirely (Although you can do some cool research/upgrades in your lab).

**And yes
recommended: i need to put this into here; Mass Effect 3 mini-review!**\nMass Effect 3 is the last game in the Mass Effect Trilogy. While the combat was the best out of the three (According to me)
hoursPlayed: the story took a major backlash thanks to the ending.\n\nBut
voteText: while the ending in the third game is absolotely horrible i can tell you one thing; The journey is a good one.\n\nThe sad truth though is that if you want to play Mass Effect 3 you have to buy it elsewhere than on Steam..."

reviewText:
10/10.

Hands down the best CRPG I've played. Above and beyond Mass Effect 1. Buy it if you enjoy science fiction and engrossing stories!

Yes, there's more action in Mass Effect's sequel, but with the better streamlined skill trees and in-combat control, it ties in very nicely with the overarching milieu's story and lore. And it's the story that really seals the deal here. The persistent characters, the evolution of your story and consequences from choices (arguably cosmetic, they still feel tangible to me),

They took everything that worked in Mass Effect 1, pared off what didn't, and made it better. It's extremely seldom that sequels are better than the originals, but Mass Effect proves exceptions do occur.

Not to be left out and this isn't intended to TMI or unncessary but merely an endorsement -- this is the second game I've played (ME1 being the first) that allows for romances that I actually participated in and enjoyed. (Note to self: I seem to play a lot of women that enjoy the company of women. Who knew?)
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: The gameplay is little bit different than the first Mass Effect but the storyline just as good. Many new interesting NPCs in addition to recurring characters from the first game. The missions are more interesting than the previous series because the levels are better defined compared to ME 1 where the interior of any building looks very similar.There is wider selection of squad members so you can employ many different tactics according to a mission's need. The squad members also have unique personalities and history that they can share with you, given you spend some time to talk to them. The loyalty missions, squad members confrontation with each other and romance really adds flavour to the game. Squad members can die in the final mission (dubbed as the Suicide Mission) resulting from failing to secure their loyalty, not making ship upgardes or choosing non-ideal person for a task in the mission. This forces the player to carefully plan and prepares for the mission. The were so many different way the game progress and ends, even the main character may be killed in the suicide mission. This gives the game a very high replay value and the player did get a bonus to the character and resources should we choose start a new game after finishing one.\n\nOverall, Mass Effect 2 is a story rich game that continues the greatness of the first game. If you want to play the game, I suggest you finish ME1 first and carry forward your character into this game. Forget about wikis and walkthrough (except when you completely stuck of course) and just follow your heart and be yourself when making decision throughout the game and you will find out the Commander Shepard you're playing really reflects the person you are (Paragon and Renegade choices). You always can play it again later if you want to experience another options that you missed before, or choosing different character to romance or whatever different options the game can offer. But remember, the outcome of the decisions can be carried to Mass Effect 3. For score, I'm giving ME2 a solid 9/10

reviewText:
Okay so the ME series was hyped by my friends so I thought I'd get it.
ME1 was not a bad game but it felt really, really slow. Liked the concept and story though, so I gave the 2nd one a spin.

One of the best investments of money you can do. Technically freeroam with Squadmember-quests similar to the companion quests in Dragon Age: Origins.

Combat is really quick and yet tactical, don't think they could've done it better. During the storyline your decisions will make an impact on the future, and you really start to like your companions. Everybody has a story and different personality, which makes this game fun even on the 5th playthrough (this is a guesstimate, just finished my first playthrough a couple of minutes ago.)

Get. This. Game. Period!
Then get ME3, like I will.

reviewText:
Best game in the series if you ask me.

+ Good story
+ Exciting missions
+ Lovely characters
+ Good graphics
+ A world that you're invested in

- Limited customization.
- Few choices in talent point placement.
- Almost no open world elements; very little exploration.
- Not many choices in weapons or tactics. Throw, lift, shockwave and singularity are also very weak since all kinds of protection block the effects. You have to push through the shields/barriers/armor to use those abilities effectively, and by then you can just keep firing until the enemy's health bar is gone.

reviewText: Belated review. Refer to my previous recommendation for Mass Effect 1 for general thoughts on the series (short version: get it). Continuing on that, Mass Effect 2 takes everything that was great about ME1 and makes it better, and at the same time completely fixes everything that was wrong. It's the perfect sequel. The only slight misstep in ME2 is the tedious planet mining mechanic. But aside from that, I really have no complaints about this game at all. It's an absolute must-play if you have any interest in the upcoming ME3. One of the coolest aspects of the series is that all of the choices you made in ME1 carry through to ME2, and will further carry through to ME3... and there are many choices to be made. It becomes a very personalized game. I should also mention that there are a number of DLC missions available as well, which are worth checking out (especially the last one). And with that, I shall say no more, as this is a game that must be played, not written about.

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game, and the series. I found myself caught up in the world, the characters, the story, the technology that to me seemed much more plausible than any other Sci-Fi universe out there (looking at you Star Wars).

Story, Characters, and World (This will cover both entries on Steam)
This is by far the best part of the Mass Effect series in my opinion, and the best part of BioWare games in general. Excellent voice acting for every character you come across blends well with the way conversations are portrayed in a pseudo-cutscene way. The dialogue was well done and interesting most of the time. There are points where hearing your character say the same things over and over in the same way get annoying, but its nothing to berate the game about.
The characters are written like characters, not NPCs. They have struggles, emotions, dreams and purposes. Just because you hear that someone didn't like this character or that character because their particular story wasn't unique" doesn't change the fact that they had a story. Mass Effect also does an outstanding job at making characters you love to love and love to hate
date: which is a teller that something was done right when this character was created.\nNow the world. Previously I said that the technology presented seemed more feasible than that of other Sci-Fi universes. This is probably more due to the amount of effort put into explaining it then it actually being scientifically plausible. The player has access to the Codex
recommended: an information catalogue that has articles on most species
voteText: locations
helpfulPercent: and history of the galaxy. And the best part? Half of it is read TO you by a narrator
votesHelpful: so you can listen to how firearms work in the year XXXX while eating Cheerios or taking a shower (don't recommend the latter). There is a large portion that you do have to read yourself
votesTotal: but most of that is the less important material. The world itself is full of diverse worlds and people
votesFunny: unique species and cool tech.\nThe story across both games is well written and intriuging without being overly complex. I won't spoil anything
commentsCount: because thats half the fun
column16:
but both games make you feel like a hero in the end.

Gameplay(ME2)
The choice system in this entry is a step up from the system in ME1. Making selfless(Paragon) choices increases your Paragon score
column17: letting you use your heroic charm to sway others
column18: and the same goes for less than level headed(Renegade) choices. In ME1
column19: you had to put skill points into your ability to charm or intimidate people
column20: which worked with the more traditional RPG style in ME1
column21: but felt like were being cheated out of choices sometimes because you focused on combat skills over being suave. The actual choices you make don't necessarily have an impact on the story overall
column22: but they change the way characters around you interact with you. There is one massive consequence based on your choices
column24: thats for you to discover.\nThe combat is a third person shooter scenario
column25: and you can use your skills and those of your allies to change the tide of battle. I have heard it compared to Gears of War
column26: but as I have never played that series
column27: I cannot compare myself. There are some adreniline filled moments in there sometimes
column29: it does kind of boil down to waiting for your enemy to peek their head out to shoot at you so you can shoot them. On lower difficulties though
column30: you can afford to be creative and reckless in your tactics
column31:
so have fun with it.

Sound and Graphics
The music is very atmospheric and I believe it was done well for the most part. The graphics are nothing to be in awe of
column32:
but this game is relatively old and the visuals are pretty good even for today.

Pros
+Great story
+Immersive world
+Witty
column34:
and real characters and dialogue
+Tough decisions make the game tense
+Use ME1 character if you finished that game
+Build relationships with your crew that matter

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game, and the series. I found myself caught up in the world, the characters, the story, the technology that to me seemed much more plausible than any other Sci-Fi universe out there (looking at you Star Wars).

Story, Characters, and World (This will cover both entries on Steam)
This is by far the best part of the Mass Effect series in my opinion, and the best part of BioWare games in general. Excellent voice acting for every character you come across blends well with the way conversations are portrayed in a pseudo-cutscene way. The dialogue was well done and interesting most of the time. There are points where hearing your character say the same things over and over in the same way get annoying, but its nothing to berate the game about.
The characters are written like characters, not NPCs. They have struggles, emotions, dreams and purposes. Just because you hear that someone didn't like this character or that character because their particular story wasn't unique" doesn't change the fact that they had a story. Mass Effect also does an outstanding job at making characters you love to love and love to hate
date: which is a teller that something was done right when this character was created.\nNow the world. Previously I said that the technology presented seemed more feasible than that of other Sci-Fi universes. This is probably more due to the amount of effort put into explaining it then it actually being scientifically plausible. The player has access to the Codex
recommended: an information catalogue that has articles on most species

reviewText:
This was initially a joke review about how this was the best dating sim ever made.
After thinking about it, I've concluded that's actually true. I had more fun with this as a dating sim than I did as a sci-fi shooter. Talking to the characters, interacting with the world, and making myself as cool as possible were my main focus while playing this.

Let's face it, the combat is okay, but it's not why I'm here.
Yeah, I'm gonna stop the Reapers and all that, but of course I am.
I wanna know, and see, and talk to everything and everyone in the meantime.

I continue to think that this game is worth a recommendation.
This was yet another Xbox 360 repurchase. It runs better on PC for damn sure.
