reviewText: My Playthrough          Youtube Playlist                 The Review        Mass Effect 2 is an interesting case. While this game does add a lot of things like more exploitable cities, more companions, and a much bigger ship. They also removed some content as well like exploring uncharted worlds with the M35 Mako, the 60 level cap, a lot of talents, and worse of all the ability to talk to your companions at any time.\nThis game does have some pros like the story is still good and the companions are well written and voice acted. The gamEplay is still the same as the prequel but now their is ammo and weapon restrictions. The cons are mostly all the things that Bioware removed from Mass Effect but a big one is that this game is far more linear than ME1. Now you can recruit any companions that you want and you have to wait for specific points to recruit your favorite companions. From all the negitives that I listed you are probably wondering why I am still recommending this game. Well while this game is not as great as Mass Effect it is still a good game and I recommend playing it.

reviewText: Following on the heels of one of my greatest gaming experiences, Mass Effect 2 does not dissapoint. The game inetegrates decisions made in the first game in suprising ways and the story line thickens even more. The perfect analogy to compare the games of Mass Effect story-wise is the old Star Wars trilogy. ME 1 is like A New Hope, everything is new and exciting. Mass Effect 2 is The Empire Strikes Back, the story is a little darker, and more serious and things aren't what they seem to be. Old Friends have left you, Your new friends will die. Like I said, the story is one of the greatest tales I've been lucky enough to experience. A great 2nd act that sets up the end to the trilogy perfeclty.

reviewText:
I'll begin with the technical aspects of the game. The first thing I notice is how considerably improved the graphics are. ME1's graphics were good, but ME2's is superior in every way. Incidentally they are also much more demanding and take up more space. I also notice that everyone wears shiny rubber for some reason.

Annoyingly, some controls got moved around. Instead of Shift bringing up the combat menu, now it's space. Considering it is one of the most used buttons in both games, this takes some serious adjusting to. It's a bit weird that Space is sort of a do-all button, and I am horribly annoyed that when you try to skip dialogs, you are likely to accidentally pick an option when a choice pops up because they just had to bind everything to that one button.

I fail to understand why they removed the minimap from the game. Instead you are given a vague cursor indicating your next objective, accessible only in the combat menu, or with M. So you need to interrupt the game in order get your bearings. I suppose this change is to encourage players to explore, but I found it more annoying than enjoyable.

There's no planetary roaming this time around, which is instead replaced with doing nothing but dumping probes onto planets to harvest resources. It's faster, I guess. The game gives far more resources than you'll need, as I had nearly 400,000 of several resources by the time I finished. On the other hand, I had a shortage of credits, as cred shops have 2 prices - dirt cheap and expensive as hell. No, seriously, a handful of items cost less than 1000. The rest cost 50k on the average.

The shooter aspect is improved, I guess. Ammo is significantly more limited this time around, and I ran out of clips more than a few times. So instead of being comfortable with one weapon the whole game, I felt a good amount of pressure in conserving ammo.

The hacking minigames are back, and thankfully they are much more varied than ME1, but they still suffer from completely shutting you out if you fail, thus prompting a reload. This is unfortunate because loading saves takes a good bit of time. They're not required most of the time, but for a first playthrough, how would anyone know if there isn't a godly item locked away in there?

The mission report at the end of every mission sort of comes abruptly out of nowhere. It's like every mission you do is being graded, and it robs immersion in my opinon.

Now onto the game itself. The story starts off kind of slowly (after the tutorial, anyway). The game's structure reminds me a bit of Fallout, where you have some key missions to do, but the rest is up to you to do in whatever order you want. Your first few missions are to gather crewmates, but for the most part these members aren't all too interesting (except for Mordin, he rules). Similar to the first game, the story becomes much more interesting towards the end, once you do the base assault and last mission.

Similar to the first game, I think this game's best point is its character conversations. This time you have nearly double the crewmates, and a fairly good amount of dialogue between them. Problem is, there's also a good number of new characters who were just plain uninteresting, namely the psycho aggressive characters or the zealots.

I can see why the game scored so well among reviewers. As cool as game as it is, I can't help but feel it would have been more suited as a turn-based game. This game earns a 8.5 from me, knocking points largely due to my detachment from the game and lack of a desire to replay it at all.

reviewText:
Mass Effect 2 is the biggest and most well made of the Mass Effect games. It is massive. Unlike in ME3, where you can only freeroam a couple of tiny spots around the Citadel, in ME2, you can free roam around massive spaces in the Citadel, Illium and Omega. I was incredibly surprised! In ME3, you have like 3 choices of where to go in  the Citadel, such as Earth Embassies, Presidium Omertia hospital and some other crap like that. In ME2, there is a massive space. Why did they leave out places like Illium?? Anyway, this review is about Mass Effect 2.

THIS GAME IS HUGE! I cannot stress that enough. Following up to Mass Effect, Bioware dramatically improved the character relationship system. Your squadmates now offer loyalty missions which you can complete and they begin to trust and respect you more. I found this quite awesome. To be honest, the ME series is the only series that made me feel any sort of emotion that wasn't sadness and frustration. I enjoyed making friends with virtual aliens. I enjoyed traveling halfway around the universe to get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ on by Collectors and their fancy ♥♥♥ indoctrinated swarms of zombies.
At times, the gameplay can be very repetitive. Kill some enemies, move forward, loot bodies, hack systems ,move forward, one of your squadmates says something, move forward, kill enemies, interact with an enemy, gain paragon or renegade. kill them.

That is the basic formula to most missions.
I am also pleased to see that they improved on the Normandy piloting system. In ME1, the Normandy was shown as a icon. Now you can see it, you can fly around using the mouse and you can scan planets with an awesome scanner that shows you mineral readings.
The storyline advances forward, introducing new friends, enemies and continuing the story of the Reapers and you stopping them.

Great game, best game in the series, what more can I say?

reviewText:
Pros:
-Characters and their interactions with each other. As you build your team, you stumble upon some very interesting people. The best aspect of the game was getting to know everybody between missions, hearing their stories, and delving deeper into the Mass Effect universe. Especially Garrus with all of his calibrations, which is everything he wants to talk about.  Then there’s the fact that you’re able to romance some of the crew members. I really felt like I was invested in and torn between some of them. Whether it was flirty Kelly, shy Tali, or (insert your description of) Miranda.
-Loyalty and crew missions. One of the reasons why you do care about the crew is permadeath. In order to get all of the crew out alive, you have to go on some loyalty missions. As you get to know everybody, crewmembers will tell you that there’s some personal problem they would like solved. Loyalty missions were the best kind of side mission because they weren’t random things to do. There was a sense of purpose—gaining a more meaningful understanding of the crew. All of them played out like a good movie should, with everybody gaining some type of character growth and a solid resolution.
-Combat is decent and can be challenging. While it reinvented the wheel, I wasn’t bored senseless. In fact, there were a few parts that I had a difficult challenge. This one part of saving Garrus took me at least ten or so tries. Mostly due to the fact that enemies will use cover effectively, (generally) work as a group, and at times actually attempt to flank you.
Mixed Bag:
-Dumbing down of rpg elements. It really seemed like there was much less of a focus on weapon diversity and putting together your gear. While it doesn’t kill the game, it certainly does make it more confusing when you buy upgrades. The upgrades tell you that it will do XYZ% more damage, but there’s no indication of how much that would be.
-Interiors seem a lot smaller. The Citadel is pathetically tiny compared to the original. And the same could be said of a lot of the places you visit. They felt small and often very linear. I really wanted to explore some of these places, but to no avail.
-No Mako, scanning only. The Mako is totally gone, which also felt like exploration was severely curtailed, and has been replaced with scanning planets. While this may on paper sound like getting resources has been streamlined—it isn’t. I did have this Minecraft mentality of collecting everything everywhere, but It’s downright boring a tedious after the fifth or so planet that you’ve scanned in the same system. By the time that you’re done with scanning every planet you’ll have an astronomically huge collection of resources.
Overall:
Mass Effect 2 is a masterpiece. There was not a lot of time that I felt like I was disengaged from the story or that I was bored doing ho-hum quests. The mythos of the universe, the strength of the characters, and the story is what elevates this game into what I consider to be near legendary. 9.5/10

reviewText: Following on the heels of one of my greatest gaming experiences, Mass Effect 2 does not dissapoint. The game inetegrates decisions made in the first game in suprising ways and the story line thickens even more. The perfect analogy to compare the games of Mass Effect story-wise is the old Star Wars trilogy. ME 1 is like A New Hope, everything is new and exciting. reviewText:
I'll begin with the technical aspects of the game. The first thing I notice is how considerably improved the graphics are. ME1's graphics were good, but ME2's is superior in every way. Incidentally they are also much more demanding and take up more space. I also notice that everyone wears shiny rubber for some reason.

Annoyingly, some controls got moved around. Instead of Shift bringing up the combat menu, now it's space. Considering it is one of the most used buttons in both games, this takes some serious adjusting to. It's a bit weird that Space is sort of a do-all button, and I am horribly annoyed that when you try to skip dialogs, you are likely to accidentally pick an option when a choice pops up because they just had to bind everything to that one button.

I fail to understand why they removed the minimap from the game. Instead you are given a vague cursor indicating your next objective, accessible only in the combat menu, or with M. So you need to interrupt the game in order get your bearings. I suppose this change is to encourage players to explore, but I found it more annoying than enjoyable.

There's no planetary roaming this time around, which is instead replaced with doing nothing but dumping probes onto planets to harvest resources. It's faster, I guess. The game gives far more resources than you'll need, as I had nearly 400,000 of several resources by the time I finished. On the other hand, I had a shortage of credits, as cred shops have 2 prices - dirt cheap and expensive as hell. No, seriously, a handful of items cost less than 1000. The rest cost 50k on the average.

The shooter aspect is improved, I guess. Ammo is significantly more limited this time around, and I ran out of clips more than a few times. So instead of being comfortable with one weapon the whole game, I felt a good amount of pressure in conserving ammo.

The hacking minigames are back, and thankfully they are much more varied than ME1, but they still suffer from completely shutting you out if you fail, thus prompting a reload. This is unfortunate because loading saves takes a good bit of time. They're not required most of the time, but for a first playthrough, how would anyone know if there isn't a godly item locked away in there?

The mission report at the end of every mission sort of comes abruptly out of nowhere. It's like every mission you do is being graded, and it robs immersion in my opinon.

Now onto the game itself. The story starts off kind of slowly (after the tutorial, anyway). The game's structure reminds me a bit of Fallout, where you have some key missions to do, but the rest is up to you to do in whatever order you want. Your first few missions are to gather crewmates, but for the most part these members aren't all too interesting (except for Mordin, he rules). Similar to the first game, the story becomes much more interesting towards the end, once you do the base assault and last mission.

Similar to the first game, I think this game's best point is its character conversations. This time you have nearly double the crewmates, and a fairly good amount of dialogue between them. Problem is, there's also a good number of new characters who were just plain uninteresting, namely the psycho aggressive characters or the zealots.

I can see why the game scored so well among reviewers. As cool as game as it is, I can't help but feel it would have been more suited as a turn-based game. This game earns a 8.5 from me, knocking points largely due to my detachment from the game and lack of a desire to replay it at all.

reviewText:
The second game in my all time favourite franchise!

Completed it 6 times and don't regret a thing!

Continuing on from the adventures of the first, you'll encounter new enemies, meet up with old friends and make new ones to once again save the galaxy from an impending threat. You'll also be able to further explore cultures of the various other species in the game, adding more depth to an already expansive universe.

Importing your save from the first game makes the experience even better, carrying over key choices you've made in the first game, allowing you to meet up with other characters that you may have helped out in side missions in the first game and also rewarding you with bonus credits and resources right off the bat plus more!

Highly Recommended! (DLC Missions are also worth playing, escpecially if you plan to play Mass Effect 3)

reviewText:
My favourite game (and it will stay like that for some time), Mass Effect 2 delivers a great story within this excellent RPG. I didn't really like the way the game starts and some controls are really horrible for keyboard users (sprint, cover and interaction are on the same button), but after a while it starts to become great. The game is filled with quests and manages to deliver a nice story while you're playing it. I really reccomend playing Mass Effect first, because this game imports your save file and all your important decisions with it (although you may change your appearance and class at the start of the game). Choice is again an important element of the game and it makes it into a personal experience. The combat mechanics are again pretty good and the ai is a bit smarter than in the original game. The voice acting is once again great, as well as the supporting characters whose personal storylines make the game even better.
One minor flaw exept for the pc controls is that the graphics aren't always the best (low-res textures), even on the highest settings, but you need to keep in mind that the game is getting pretty old.
Windows 8 users might need to use Windows xp sp3 compability mode and (if you're using it) you need to turn of Lucid Virtu MVP to play without crashes.

Summary:
Story: 9,7/10
Gameplay: 9,5/10
Graphics: 7/10
Sound: 8,5/10 (+ excellent voice acting)

Score: 9,8/10

reviewText:
An absolute improvement over ME1, altough not perfect.

Controls are completely revamped; confusing at first if you were expecting the same as ME1. The pace is quicker and the gameplay more fluid and interesting. The plot has some twists and the narrative is better. There are varoius ways to end this adventure, all different depending on what you did and how you played. You can feel the consecuences of your actions. The final mission is one of the best I've ever played: complex, dramatic, not absurdly hard but not easier either, and it will make you care for your crew and squadmates.

Story is better and richer, and the drama more polished. The game knows how to keep tension, both aboard the Normandy and in combat. The variety of missions means you'll not get bored with repetitiveness as in some other games. The music sets the ambience darker than the first game, but still top notch.

Mass Effect universe's lore keeps expanding, new characters bring alternatives and the old ones return, but with little participation. Philosophical issues keep the conversations smart for those with intellect, and nice voice acting will satisfy the impatient. Romance has now more options.

The devs got rid of the confusing inventory system in favor of a bare-bones approach to weapons that completely removes the RPG-item feel. This is not necesarily a bad thing. The character building also got simpler.

Mako exploration with its super-steep mountains is gone for good. DLC has a nicer hover vehicle, more agile and fun. I recommend getting the Digital Deluxe Edition: the extra content is worth it.

If you own ME1 and liked it, do yourself a favor and play Mass Effect 2.

reviewText: Just... Amazing. This game deserves it all. One of the best purchases that I have ever made on steam. I would lie if I said this is not my favorite RPG game of all time. EVERYTHING is up to the player. Who lives, who dies, what happens, how you play, how you approach a situation, how to fix it? (Or not fix it because you decide to be a ruthless a**hole) it's totally up to you! What I like most about this game is that you don't choose only the small stuff, no. You get to change the entire storyline. You definitely get to be deeply attached to the characters in the game, and know their background story. The soundtracks, the missions, the stories, the lore... Everything is just amazing. Each choice you make will have reprecussions, and this time, I mean it. Even in the sequel! The choices you make in the game WILL have a very huge impact on your gameplay in ME3, so choose wisely! A must get game.

reviewText: I've been thinking what to write about this game for a while. Let me just start by saying that when I first tried it, I disliked it. I started it directly after the original Mass Effect and I noticed several changes. The RPG-ish system from the first Mass Effect game changed a lot. The game is more shooter-like, the inventory doesn't exist anymore, you suddenly need ammo". All these changes made me very bitter about this game. But I continued playing and soon began to get used to this system
date: maybe even prefer it. You don't have to freak out every time you're nearing the item limit for your inventory like in the original ME. The combat is more intuitive and requires less franctic running around. The ammo thing
recommended: you can get used to it
hoursPlayed: at least the weapons don't overheat anymore. The only downside I found was the overly simplified skill system. Not bad
voteText: but I preferred the original one.\n\nStory-wise

reviewText: Let me make this clear from the start... I don't think this is better than ME1. Yes, it has a couple of very well implemented new features, but it also removed some of the best features of the first one. Let me explain why it has some shortcomings. First of all; they removed the elevator loading scenes, which is actually a major plus. They also removed the random loot, and the ability to upgrade these weapons. Now, I'm one that loves loot so why oh why did they remove it ? I really hope they will implement it back into the third one. And why remove the optional buggy ? It was kinda cool (but not always fun). A major plus is that there are different planets, a few of them with their own atmosphere. I really wish there were more of these planets because there weren't enough of them. Maybe something for ME3 as well. Last but not least; it's shorter. Know this, it's a great game and you really should play it, but if you loved the first one like I did you might get disappointed.\n\n[Rating: 92/100]

reviewText:
This is coming way too late as I've played the game half a year ago.
ME2 is an overall improvement over the first title in almost any aspect, be it graphical fidelity, combat handling or story depth, and I totally recommend it at any time. For context reasons, I always recommend playing the trilogy in its chronological order though. Despite that I find the game excellent, there's a few points I need to criticise:
- Squadmates. There's a lot of possible squadmates. My problem with them is not that they are hallow, barely fleshed out characters (none of them are, really), but the number is just too impractical. You never get to choose all of them often enough because you can always just choose two at once.
- Gun variety. While the first title technically had lots of different guns (although they handled all pretty much the same), the amount of different weapons in ME2 is very limited and therefore fairly disappointing. You know there's a lack of content if you end up using the same pistol endgame that you had at the beginning.
- The amount of DLCs and their price. Most of the DLCs are solid story additions and a must-have for anyone who wishes to experience the ME universe to its full extent. They are, however, pricey and numerous, and while I bought most of them legally for ME2, I went for.. less conventional ways in the 3rd title simply because I cannot support this 'DLC fad' of the last years (1st day DLCs are the pinnacle of intentional content restriction in order to milk more money from customers, I'm looking at you, EA)

9/10.

reviewText:
A well-rounded and very solid sequel to the original. It improves on the first game in almost every aspect. The combat feels more fluid and much more fun, the graphics, story, and sound are better than ever.

It plays much like the original - an over the shoulder action/RPG. If you liked the first one, you will love this. There are reoccurring characters from the first game and the ability to import your ME1 character, along with all the decisions (and consequences). A really nice touch.

My only (minor) gripes is that the inventory and level-up system seems even further dumbed down compared to the first one. A definate con for those of you that like customisation in their RPGs. The galaxy map is also a little silly (and pointless). These however, are nit-picking an otherwise superb game - a game that it probably on my top 10 games of all time. Everyone should play it. Period.

Jimbo Rating: 9/10

reviewText:
Sequel to the critically acclaimed game Mass Effect, Mass Effect 2 takes the beloved franchise from great to magnificent. The storyline, voice acting, visuals, and the 3rd-person combat system with a sci-fi twist work flawlessly. It is a masterpiece of our generation, to say the least.

In this sci-fi action RPG the player takes on the role of Commander Shepard who must save the world once again, this time from mysterious beings called “The Collectors”. Before they destroy humanity, Shepard must travel the universe and recruit a team of humans and aliens, gain their loyalty, research the enemy, and stop the Collectors at all cost.

In many ways Mass Effect 2 embodies what Bioware is all about. Players will appreciate not only the top quality storyline and voice acting -- Martin Sheen steals the show -- but also the lengths Bioware went to listen to their fans and improve on the flaws of the previous game. One example of such improvement is the switch from the cool-down weapons to the traditional magazine-reload weapons. While many developers would have kept their old “innovative” system, due to either pride or laziness, Bioware went the extra mile to make the changes -- and it paid off. Other changes such as simpler weapon customization and tighter combat controls make for a more satisfying experience overall compared to its predecessor. The save file from the previous game carries over as well, which is another welcome trademark of Bioware.

The presentation of the game is flawless. Including everything from visuals, audio, and writing, Mass Effect 2 does not fail in the “epic experience” department, the most impressive aspect being the characters themselves. Bioware has taken the time to create such compelling characters that I had no choice but to care about every single one of them. The universe of Mass Effect 2 is deep, thoughtfully-crafted, and engaging, just like its predecessor, which is full of codex entries that pull the players deeper still into the futuristic world. Add to it the attention to detail such as the great soundtrack and the subtle biblical references throughout the game and you get yourself an unforgettable experience.

The 3rd-person combat is very satisfying as well. Not only is the gunplay improved compared to the previous game, but the use of special skills has tightened up as well, giving much more incentive for the player to try out classes other than the gun expert Soldier class (being an Adept with telekinetic powers is incredibly satisfying, not to mention all the other classes).

Ironically, the weak point of this game is also its selling point -- the morality system. Yes, it does have a morality system that very much controls the tone of the playthrough; but it lacks the complexity and the ambiguity that makes such systems… well… so delicious (Dragon Age, a Bioware game with such deliciousness, comes to mind). The player’s choices are always presented in a very clear manner that just boils them down to “good” or “bad” in the end. In my first playthrough I was interested in what Sheperd would do in a given situation but after a while I found myself just clicking the “good” option (as I was playing the “good” character) without even reading the actual response, which made me much less appreciative of the morality system. Other weak points include the sub-par vehicular DLC “Firewalker Pack” and the shallow and two-dimensional “romance” system.

Mass Effect 2 is one of the few games in which I began a second playthrough immediately after the first one. It is a game I’ll revisit at least once a year, like a classic book that gets better each time you read it. Is it the morality system that changes the tone of the game? Is it the compelling characters that I can’t keep away from? Maybe it is the engaging combat with multiple classes to choose from. Or maybe it is just the sheer polish of the script and voice acting. Whatever it is, there is no denying that Mass Effect 2 is something special. Even if you are not a sci-fi fan, even if you are not an RPG fan, or even if you are not a third person shooter fan, it would be a damn shame if I didn’t recommend this game with all my heart.

reviewText: To put it simply, this is one of the best games ever made. The memorable characters, great story, and interactivity of this game really made it memorable. The combat is much better than in the original game, that getting into fights was less of a chore and more fun. Every single mission felt like it had a purpose, and the lack of the cut and paste mission design was much appreciated. I did every character's loyalty mission so they wouldn't die because I was invested in the characters. This game also had some of the greatest DLC I have ever played. Lair of the Shadow Broker was incredible, and the other DLC was fun too. Overall this game is the complete package, and a good sequel always surpasses the original. Mass Effect 2 does just that.

reviewText:
My favourite game (and it will stay like that for some time), Mass Effect 2 delivers a great story within this excellent RPG. I didn't really like the way the game starts and some controls are really horrible for keyboard users (sprint, cover and interaction are on the same button), but after a while it starts to become great. The game is filled with quests and manages to deliver a nice story while you're playing it. I really reccomend playing Mass Effect first, because this game imports your save file and all your important decisions with it (although you may change your appearance and class at the start of the game). Choice is again an important element of the game and it makes it into a personal experience. The combat mechanics are again pretty good and the ai is a bit smarter than in the original game. The voice acting is once again great, as well as the supporting characters whose personal storylines make the game even better.
One minor flaw exept for the pc controls is that the graphics aren't always the best (low-res textures), even on the highest settings, but you need to keep in mind that the game is getting pretty old.
Windows 8 users might need to use Windows xp sp3 compability mode and (if you're using it) you need to turn of Lucid Virtu MVP to play without crashes.

Summary:
Story: 9,7/10
Gameplay: 9,5/10
Graphics: 7/10
Sound: 8,5/10 (+ excellent voice acting)

Score: 9,8/10

reviewText: This game is f***ing amazing. Alright, alright. The combat basically plays like a cover shooter and the RPG elements are severely lacking. But, buuuuut. If you like story driven immersive games then you will love Mass Effect 2. You don't need to have played the first Mass Effect because most of the lore is transferred through dialogue and codex entrees so you'll be just fine, but if you have played Mass Effect 1 you will feel alot more connected to the world and to Shepard's companions. On the point of companions, the characters in this game are just great, they are excellently voice acted and by the end, hell by the middle of the game you'll feel genuinely connected to your companions. The choices made throughout this game kind of matters in the game but if you play the whole trilogy from the first Mass Effect then you'll see the real effect of your choices on the galaxy. So what are you doing reading this review, you're wasting time not playing Mass Effect 2, buy it now and save the galaxy.

reviewText:
Wow.

It's hard to overstate how much I enjoyed this game. It is masterful on every level - story, writing, scope, decision making, combat, environmental design, artwork, lighting effects, cinematography, musical score, sound design, and virtually any other area I can think of. It is, without exaggeration, that good.

(mini spoiler) And the last mission - any team member you have come to know in the game can die a very permanent death based on your decisions, giving the finale a weight and consequence rarely experienced in video games. (end mini spoiler)

What is perhaps most staggering is that even after a 50-hour playthrough (DLC included), you can be sure that you have seen far less than even half of the possibilities that the game has to offer. The original game isn't nearly as perfect, but still worth a run-through for the storyline and decisions that will carry over into the sequel.

No, the game is not without faults. For one thing, it's overly easy and overly simplified compared to the original.

It doesn't have the same level of cinematic polish that we've come to expect from AAA titles in 2013 and beyond.

It gets excessively talkative and stale in certain areas.

Much like the previous game, the romance subplots are stupid. If you want your Commander Shepard to get some quick and casual sex, it's not gonna happen. It's deep love or nothing. And that deep love comes out of nowhere, since your intimate conversations with any given love interest are extremely limited.

But by far the worst of Mass Effect 2's problems is the very time-consuming process of grinding for resources, which isn't any fun at all. There are nearly endless amounts of resources available, but the game doesn't tell you how many you need. While there are ship upgrades available later in the game to make these processes quicker, the game doesn't tell you about them, and so you may waste much time in the first half grinding before acquiring them. My advice: grind at a minimum until you get the upgrades, and then only focus on rich" planets
date:
since there are more than enough to get you through.

(Issues)
I want to mention a few minor issues that you might run into. I frequently clipped through objects and got stuck
hoursPlayed: and there are a few missions tied to DLC that resulted in game-breaking crashes. The latter problem was easily rectified by creating a shortcut to the .exe and putting -nomoviestartup in the parameters. One last very strange glitch resulted in my player character stretching her arms out to the sides
voteText: unable to shoot or interact anymore
helpfulPercent: solved only by reloading an earlier save and trying different dialogue choices before the bug. With a game this big
votesHelpful: my recommendation is to keep numerous save files and save often.\n\nOverall
votesTotal: Mass Effect 2 is definitely one of my favorite games of 2010
votesFunny: matched only by Red Dead Redemption. In my book

that's saying a lot.


9/10"

reviewText: Undoubtedly the most amazing game I have ever played. Breathtaking cinematics, engaging storyline, original characters. Everything about this game makes it a perfect 10/10 for me. The combat system is highly interpretive and the feel of command and control over your three-man squadron is unparalleled. I found myself on the edge of my seat more time than not; not to mention heartbroken, overjoyed, and so many other emotions. The worst part about this game is that I didn't search every nook and cranny of the universe in order to make the game continue; I hate how it's actually over. No game will ever come close to meaning as much as this game does to me.

reviewText:
I didn't know much about what type of game mass effect was until I started playing this.  Now, after I practically played it straight through (few breaks), it's easily one of the best games I've ever played.  Despite never playing or looking up what happened in the first mass effect, this game is still amazing.

The fighting mechanics and biotic aspect is enough to make this game really fun, but the story and how it's told makes it so much better.  It's like a movie that you can direct. . . in real time @_@.  Some of the scenes are a bit cliche, but not annoying cliche; it's cliche done right.  I will definitely be playing this again in the future (several times).

Highly, highly recommended

reviewText:
Bioware seems to have perfected story writing, at least at this point in the trilogy. They lose some points for changing the control system completely from the first game, and from the stantard fps control; it would be O.K. except for laziness in not teaching the dialogues to adjust to custom controls. It hurt in a few time-sensitive, unique settings.

Ammo was a big change and having the entire canon universe switch in two years is a little hard to swallow. I guess that with the addition of regenerating health, they had to make your character weaker somehow, and they dump loads more enemies on you this time around. I kind of missed how easily you could get pwned in the first one, even while I mowed down armies in this game.

Dislike the shallow skillsets of the characters. Companions literally have 3 abilities, and then a bonus one after loyalty missions.

These are the only problems, and literally every other part of the game is, at worst, 7/10. I rate 88/100 overall. Will probably play again.

reviewText:
Here's a confusing review for you, i'm recommending the game yet i am not a fan of it.

Look, it's a good game, i'm sure there are a lot of people out there that will play the ♥♥♥♥ out of it and absolutely adore it, but personally i didn't. I wasn't as immersed in the game as i would've liked, i felt disconnected from the action (I put it down to me disliking third person modes), i also had several performance and reliability issues that made me incredibly frustrated. (Like seriously, there was a part that i had to redo 20 times because my character would inexplicably fly into the air and become fodder for the enemies weapons).

It is worth the money, it's a decent £19.99 to spend on a game even though it's a few years old, but coming from someone who wasn't a fan of the original game, i'm not as bowled over as i expected from the massive buildup i got.

reviewText: If you like sci-fi, guns, best friends and saving the galaxy, this game is for you. I've never been so immersed into a game as I have with the Mass Effect series. The only downsides I can really say about the game is that it relies a little too much on borrowing elements from Bioware's other games (mostly KOTOR), and that there isn't a Game of the Year edition. That being said, it's still worth your time even without the DLC. The Mass Effect games have quickly become some of my favorite games of all time. The story-telling in this game is incredible, and you will get sucked in. I also highly recommend playing this game with an imported character from ME1 in order to get the most out of it.

reviewText:
The second instalment in a legendary game series.  There is no way for this game to be better.  None.  It took everything from the first game and took it to the next level.  While playable without the first game it does strongly affect story depth.  The detail that comes out due to past actions is truely impressive.  Play this game.  And its precursor.  And its sequel.  (the third game)

As with the first game I have only one real con with this game:  Mass Effect 3 is not available on Steam.  Not cool EA.

10/10

reviewText:
JK ME1 NEEDED IMPROVEMENT and it got it but the changes between me1 and two were very jarring. UI and combat functions were so much easier in ME1. What is this bull about needing fuel and ammo? Not having ammo was the best part of ME1. Why would you take that away from me.

tbh it's still about as fun as ME1 and the story parts are just as good (I can't believe I went for the straight romance on my first full playthrough though I am a horrible person) but they have added enough new and extremely obnoxious features that they are somewhat detrimental to my enjoyment of the series. idk maybe I'll be able to ignore them once I get farther in, but still. edit: yeah i was def able to ignore them and now i miss them.

why ammo. I hate having to find ammo. And trying to figure out weapons upgrades is ridiculous. What did you do to my galaxy map. wtf is this hacking things now *taps on keyboard* im in. and the medi-gel thing too (although I am actually okay with how they changed the health meter and stuff, it's more Halo-y). WHY AMMO.

upd8 to this review: I feel like I'm playing DnD, but I didn't get to roll the character. This new character was based on my old one, but I'm now sorta Chaotic Good at best instead of Lawful Good, and my DM is an over controlling **** who specifically designs the campaign to not let me switch ever, driving away all my old loved ones because I am forced to work for the bad guys I was specifically investigating on the side for their illegal experiments and xenophobia, none of which I am about. AND xe's making me scavenge for ammo. What the heck.

upd8 to my upd8: having beaten the game, the stupid ammo thing gets less annoying over time, but it's still annoying and I don't like it. However, I freaking love that sniper rifle I call 'er Vera. It makes up for it. The Chaotic Good thing also still stands and why is there not an option for me to punch the **** out of the Smoking M- I mean the Illusive Man?

upd8 many months later: yeaaaaah so I'm replaying ME1 now and. There are some things I definitely don't miss in ME2. So my first opinion is now incorrect.

reviewText: Following on the heels of one of my greatest gaming experiences, Mass Effect 2 does not dissapoint. The game inetegrates decisions made in the first game in suprising ways and the story line thickens even more. The perfect analogy to compare the games of Mass Effect story-wise is the old Star Wars trilogy. ME 1 is like A New Hope, everything is new and exciting. Mass Effect 2 is The Empire Strikes Back, the story is a little darker, and more serious and things aren't what they seem to be. Old Friends have left you, Your new friends will die. Like I said, the story is one of the greatest tales I've been lucky enough to experience. A great 2nd act that sets up the end to the trilogy perfeclty.

reviewText:
I'll begin with the technical aspects of the game. The first thing I notice is how considerably improved the graphics are. ME1's graphics were good, but ME2's is superior in every way. Incidentally they are also much more demanding and take up more space. I also notice that everyone wears shiny rubber for some reason.

Annoyingly, some controls got moved around. Instead of Shift bringing up the combat menu, now it's space. Considering it is one of the most used buttons in both games, this takes some serious adjusting to. It's a bit weird that Space is sort of a do-all button, and I am horribly annoyed that when you try to skip dialogs, you are likely to accidentally pick an option when a choice pops up because they just had to bind everything to that one button.

I fail to understand why they removed the minimap from the game. Instead you are given a vague cursor indicating your next objective, accessible only in the combat menu, or with M. So you need to interrupt the game in order get your bearings. I suppose this change is to encourage players to explore, but I found it more annoying than enjoyable.

There's no planetary roaming this time around, which is instead replaced with doing nothing but dumping probes onto planets to harvest resources. It's faster, I guess. The game gives far more resources than you'll need, as I had nearly 400,000 of several resources by the time I finished. On the other hand, I had a shortage of credits, as cred shops have 2 prices - dirt cheap and expensive as hell. No, seriously, a handful of items cost less than 1000. The rest cost 50k on the average.

The shooter aspect is improved, I guess. Ammo is significantly more limited this time around, and I ran out of clips more than a few times. So instead of being comfortable with one weapon the whole game, I felt a good amount of pressure in conserving ammo.

The hacking minigames are back, and thankfully they are much more varied than ME1, but they still suffer from completely shutting you out if you fail, thus prompting a reload. This is unfortunate because loading saves takes a good bit of time. They're not required most of the time, but for a first playthrough, how would anyone know if there isn't a godly item locked away in there?

The mission report at the end of every mission sort of comes abruptly out of nowhere. It's like every mission you do is being graded, and it robs immersion in my opinon.

Now onto the game itself. The story starts off kind of slowly (after the tutorial, anyway). The game's structure reminds me a bit of Fallout, where you have some key missions to do, but the rest is up to you to do in whatever order you want. Your first few missions are to gather crewmates, but for the most part these members aren't all too interesting (except for Mordin, he rules). Similar to the first game, the story becomes much more interesting towards the end, once you do the base assault and last mission.

Similar to the first game, I think this game's best point is its character conversations. This time you have nearly double the crewmates, and a fairly good amount of dialogue between them. Problem is, there's also a good number of new characters who were just plain uninteresting, namely the psycho aggressive characters or the zealots.

I can see why the game scored so well among reviewers. As cool as game as it is, I can't help but feel it would have been more suited as a turn-based game. This game earns a 8.5 from me, knocking points largely due to my detachment from the game and lack of a desire to replay it at all.

reviewText:
pretty decent/10

i assume you're one of the types that played mass effect 1 before and not one of those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that jump in mid series. why the ♥♥♥♥ would you do that, anyways?

controls are solid, though if you're left handed like me and use insert, home, pgup and end for keybinds, you can't keybind i think either delete or pgdown for an ability. so that's disappointing. no weird mouse acceleration [i think. been years]

ui is kinda dumb since things are so streamlined for console users. weapon switching hud feels dumb and i just want everything laid out instead of things fanning out when i hover over a gun.

graphics are okay. i don't give a ♥♥♥♥ about mass effect graphics and neither should you. although the design for human faces look dumb. they should've worked on that.

ship is really fun to explore, and so is talkin w/ my alien bros [human characters are terrible just like mass effect 1]

i'm in the minority here, but i don't like how me2 is essentially gears of war in space. i rather liked the [extremely basic] rpg elements in me1, and managing inventory w/ the different types of armor and weapon and implant mods. the changes to classes is pretty great, though, and the various abilities are nice.

story is meh. they hint towards some interesting things which would've been great if they had some impact in mass effect 3 but they lead to nowhere due to the ♥♥♥♥ writers at bioware ♥♥♥♥ing things up. speaking of which, the story for me2 is entirely pointless. the reveals and ♥♥♥♥ have no impact in the galaxy at large. things that should. but don't, because bioware employs middle school level fan fiction writers. also everyone has daddy issues and most of the game is focused on fixing the problems of crewmembers. which wouldn't be an issue if they didn't ♥♥♥♥ing matter in me3. nothing matters

♥♥♥♥ bioware

anyways, def would recommend/10, and ignore my conflicted feelings of the series. just don't pay money for me3.

Think Call of Duty is the best ♥♥♥♥ ever? You're ♥♥♥♥ing wrong. This is the best ♥♥♥♥ ever.
